review.title: Evaluating Classifiers in Detecting 419 Scams in Bilingual Cybercriminal Communities
review.abstract: Incidents of organized cybercrime are rising because of criminals are reaping high financial rewards while incurring low costs to commit crime. As the digital landscape broadens to accommodate more internet-enabled devices and technologies like social media, more cybercriminals who are not native English speakers are invading cyberspace to cash in on quick exploits. In this paper we evaluate the performance of three machine learning classifiers in detecting 419 scams in a bilingual Nigerian cybercriminal community. We use three popular classifiers in text processing namely: Na\"ive Bayes, k-nearest neighbors (IBK) and Support Vector Machines (SVM). The preliminary results on a real world dataset reveal the SVM significantly outperforms Na\"ive Bayes and IBK at 95% confidence level.

sections.heading: A. Nigerian Bilingual Cybercriminals and 419 Scams
sections.text: This work examines the detection of 419 scams within an abilingual community of cybercriminals. These scams are known as advance fraud or 419 scams [9], [10]. 419 scams originated in Nigeria on a smaller scale in the 1970s, but escalated into posted letters in the 1980s during the oil boom, and then culminated in the commercialization of the Internet into e-mails in the 1990s. [11] Over time, the origin of 419 scams expanded to various West African countries such as Ghana, Cameroon, Ivory Coast, Benin, and other parts of the world. Although these scams are not usually reported, a 2013 report found that victims lost $12.7 billion this year to this category of cybercriminals [11]. Cyber criminals, which include 419 scams, speak bilingual English.

sections.heading: B. Content-based Cybercrime Detection
sections.text: Various research has examined the detection of various types of content-related cybercrime, such as fraud, phishing and spam [12], [13]. Wang et al., investigate social spam to build a social spam detection framework that filters spam across multiple social networks, namely: MySpace, Twitter and WebbSpam Corpus [14]. Bosma et al., develop a social spam detection framework that uses linking analysis and implements this in a popular social network [15]. Bhat et al., propose a community-based framework and use ensemble classifiers to detect spammers within community nodes in online social networks [16], [17]. sections.heading: A. Dataset Description
sections.text: For our experimental study, we first generated two primary datasets from datasets randomly selected from the 150 Facebook accounts with high PageRank values. Primary dataset 1 (PD1) contains only English datasets, while Primary dataset 2 (PD2) has half the datasets in English and the other half in Nigerian Pidgin, as shown in Table 1. The data in each primary dataset is labeled and then pre-processed to remove all non-ASCII characters, symbols and punctuation marks, except for the apostrophes we escape. The data used in our classification problem are in two languages, namely English and Nigerian Pidgin, which both use Latin characters and therefore do not use special symbols or non-ASCII characters, which is typical in languages such as French, Spanish, etc., which use such characters to highlight accents for certain words. However, there was evidence in the ASCII form for the use of non-ASCII characters in some emoticons.

sections.heading: B. Classifier Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: Our study uses binary classifications to train and test instances of text in the records as fraud or non-fraud. To evaluate our classifiers, we use recall, precision and F1 measurements of uniform and Bigram word vectors. Recall measures the percentage of fraud messages detected, so this measure determines how well a classifier performs in identifying a condition. However, precision measures how many of the fraud messages are correctly detected, so this is a measure of the likelihood that a predicted result is the correct one [28]. F1 measurement is a harmonious tool for precision and recall. Let's leave xns → ns the number of non-fraud posts that are classified as non-fraud, xns → s the number of non-fraud posts that are classified as fraud, xs → ns the number of non-fraud posts that are classified as fraud, xs → ns the number of incorrect fraud posts, xs = the number of rectified posts.

sections.heading: C. Experimental Setup
sections.text: To solve our classification problem, we use three classifiers, namely: Naïve Bayes (NB) [30], Support Vector Machines (LibSVM) and k-Nearest Neighbor (IBK) [26]. To get the results, each of the randomly collected subdata sets is divided into training and testing tests. 80% of the data in each subdata set is randomly allocated for training and 20% for testing. In addition, we used a 10x cross-validation method to improve the performance of the classifiers. By means of cross-validation, each of the four subdata sets was divided into 10 sets in equal parts.
